events.description: The end of the Iran-Iraq War increased oil production from both countries, impacting global supply.
Iraq's invasion of Kuwait caused a spike in oil prices due to concerns over supply disruptions in the Middle East.
The financial crisis in Asia led to a drop in demand for oil, causing prices to decline.
The terrorist attacks in the U.S. led to market uncertainty and a temporary dip in oil demand.
The invasion created concerns over supply security in the Middle East, pushing prices higher.
The economic downturn reduced global oil demand, causing a sharp drop in oil prices.
Political instability across the Middle East led to concerns about oil production and supply, causing price fluctuations.
OPEC decided to cut oil production to stabilize prices after a period of low oil prices due to oversupply.
The re-imposition of sanctions on Iran reduced its oil exports, impacting global supply and pushing prices up.
Global lockdowns and reduced travel caused a significant drop in demand, leading to a major collapse in oil prices.
The invasion of Ukraine by Russia led to concerns over oil supply, especially in Europe, pushing oil prices higher.
